reviewText:
I feel the need to clarify. This game is not art, it's ridiculous. It obviously doesn't appeal to everybody. What you'd be buying is essentially a better version of LSD Dream Emulator, if you don't find that concept interesting already, this isn't for you. I just want readers to understand my position before going into this, I like new ideas and interesting concepts, and I think games should be allowed to be whatever their creators please. People who feel the same way as me will probably get quite a bit out of this game.

Soda Drinker Pro was initially released in 2008 after it's short development time of one day. Now I've always thought ♥♥♥♥ like this was nonsense and shouldn't even cost money, but over the years it's been worked on and actually has an awful lot of content in it now. I never thought my purchase of digital Soda Drinking Simulation would eventually provide me with an interesting and enjoyable experience.

No, I'm not talking about Soda Drinker Pro. For some reason, the dude who made this decided to take his Malware looking joke program and put an actual video game in it, it used to be that you had to stare a rock for about 3 minutes in order to get into the secret game, but I believe the method has changed now. In this game, you play as a raindrop and touch different objects, turning into whatever you touch. If you know LSD dream emulator, imagine it being like that but with continuety, things to do and an awful lot of work put into it. And honestly, as I played more of Vivian clark, the secret game, I started to warm up more to the idea of Soda Drinker Pro itself. A game that looks like another one of those worthless simulator" games that nobody likes
date: but has a cult following because of Vivian Clark.\n\nThe most you're gonna get out of Soda Drinker Pro is some laughs with your friends
recommended: exploring and listening to all the bizarre nonsense it has. If you want a better version of Soda Drinker Pro
hoursPlayed: then buy Soda Drinker Pro and play Vivian Clark.\n\nFeel me?"
voteText: April 14

reviewText:
This game is terrifying in a primal, gutteral, mind-expanding kind of way. Don't play this before you go to sleep.

I'll fully admit I haven't plumbed every depth of this experience, but it goes places I could never have thought. Weird, dark, abject horror places. Places that will make you think about how you approach life.

This isn't a funny review. This is legit a mind-bengingly transformative experience.
voteText: 20 of 27 people (74%) found this review helpful 4 people found this review funny

reviewText:
What a ridiculous game. That pretty much summarizes the reaction I had when I first saw Soda Drinker Pro in action. The game really just serves as a front for the real game, Vivian Clark. I found this to be a strange design decision, but given the absurd nature of this game, I guess it fits well.

Soda Drinker Pro is a joke, through and through. There really isn't anything redeeming about it in terms of gameplay, but I was impressed by the fact that seemingly every level has a line recorded about that level when it starts up. That alone probably took a few hours to record.

Vivian Clark, on the other hand, is an artsy little game that reminds me heavily of Wario Ware. You go back and forth between goofy minigames that are as fun as they are outrageous. These minigames connect to other ones, usually by bumping into an object or even by failing in a certain way, which creates a maze for the player to navigate through. Vivian Clark is very much a maze of minigames that tests your memory as you try to figure out how to get back to game X to continue exploring new ones you haven't discovered yet.

So do I recommend this game? Yeah, I think so. It's a fun little game to show off to friends or stream. I'd wait for a sale to pick it up though, because I think the entertainment it offers is pretty limited.

reviewText:
Ever wanted to share a brewski with your dad? Suffer crippling depression over the fact that your best friend in the world is a horrible deformity? How about drink a soda, while INSIDE a soda?

All this and more can be yours over the course of 118 EXCITING levels; soon you'll wonder how you ever got through life without a soda in your hand at all times.

Oh, also there's an actual enjoyable game hidden in there somewhere, but that's not important.

reviewText: The hidden surrealist art game within this is not bad, but it's also really not good, either. reviewText:
(CONTEXT: Only saw the trailer before playing the game, so maybe I'm missing some crucial inside jokes)

EDIT: Welp, seems I actually missed an inside joke, so this review below only applies for the SDPro part of the game. If you're reading this remember to check out level 2 extensively for the actual, pretty cool, super-secret game!

This game is probably one of the more confusing and frustrating experiences I've played ever, not because it's 100%, unsalvagebly bad but because it has some genious elements drowned in a sea of boringness and contradictory gameplay decisions that in the end just don't work.

First of all, the positives:

-Music: If there's something that shines on this game it's the music. There's over 120 tracks of a guy singing about how he loves soda and it doesn't get stale at all, just the oposite, it became the only reason I played through the whole game, just to see what the next music sounds like. So bravo, sound design guy :D

-Some of the levels: There are a few levels that were pretty interesting, like 2 and 69 from the top of my head, and a few more that the concept was pretty funny/bizarre/dissonant with the previous level that really made me burst out laughing.

-Soda Drinking: Duh. Probably one of the smartest choices was letting you advance to the next level whenever you want after a short forced period of exploring, kind of like the camera part of Sonic Dreams Collection (which you should probably play), specially considering on how many levels you can fall off the map.

-Hugely configurable Soda: Cafeine is not too healthy for me so it's nice that they included caffeine-free soda alternatives :)

Negatives:

-The walk speed: Uuuuuuuuurgh. The worst part of all is that the dev definitely intentionally screws with the player in this front, as in some levels you can only walk at a decent pace while going sideways or even backwards, like in Big Rigs (which is not too far off from this game, actually :D), and it changes on a per-level basis, so it gets even more anoying by making you check which is the correct way of walking before actually exploring a level.

-Slurping makes you unable to hear what the songs are saying: Which can be fixed" with a bug that makes you able to drink soda silently but it's still not a good idea to make the more entretaining part of the game harder to experience.

-Generally Bland Levels: And here's the main problem I had
date: the levels where waaaaaaaay too empty
recommended: specially after Level 2 being so jam-packed with awesome secrets which set your expectations waaaaaaaay too high
hoursPlayed: and with the walk speed being waaaaaaaay too low which forces you to strafe-walk
voteText: which in turn ends up with you looking at a wall for 50% of the time you're playing.\n\n-The mouse isn't hidden when playing: Ha ha
helpfulPercent: what a chuckle-worthy amateur ironic inconvenience we did that every other bad game developer also does. Still doesn't make it less annoying though.\n\nIn conclusion

reviewText:
I paid $10 for a virtual soda drinking game, and have absolutely no regrets.

Now it's clear to see that this game is actually just an abstract interpretation of Dostoevsky's greatest works, and really represents the amount of time and sweat put into his novels. I'll admit though, around the time you start drinking soda by a pool, it gets really political, and maybe even philosophical in nature, as seen when you're drinking soda on top of a rooftop, (WTC anyone? Illuminati? Wake up sheeple!) So basically what I mean to say is,

If you like soda, it's a 10/10
If you don't like soda, it's a 10/10
If your best friend's brother's girlfriend is a cheating ho, he should dump her

and then buy soda drinker pro because it's a 10/10.

This game is perfection, and paying $10 for this piece of art is a STEAL, all of those original Van Gogh's I bought to help start that fire in california those months back cost me millions, but this game is cheap, flawless, and beautiful.

reviewText:
When I was a child, I had a dream. A dream to one day sip soda in space.
Unfortunately for me, I don't have the aptitude to pass the rigorous tests required by NASA astronauts.
Then came Soda Drinker Pro.
Now I can experience the sensation of the carbonated cosmos as I veeeeery slowly crawl my way across not only space, but over a hundred locations where a person can only dream of drinking soda.

Have you even been on top of a skyscraper? You have? Well I'll bet dollars to sodas you weren't sipping something tasty while you were up there. Well now you can!

From familiar locations, to the very limit of human soda shenanigans, you, too, can experience what it's like to enjoy caffeinated slurpers the way they were meant to be enjoyed.

You can see where it all begins in the soda factory, or experience soda-ception as you drink soda into your mouth... INSIDE a human mouth! It has only just begun!
voteText: 46 of 130 people (35%) found this review helpful 23 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Never in my life has a game encouraged me so wholeheartedly to enjoy it without even trying.

I think that's the beauty with a game like this.

On paper, walking around drinking a virtual soda doesn't seem like much, but when you let yourself actually give it a chance you'll find that over 40 levels have already gone by, and you and your friends are anxiously anticipating what weird and interesting levels come next.

Video games at its core should always be about having fun, and if you are able to find the fun in drinking a simulated soda in places like the skate park or the moon then you will fall in love with this game.

Pros:

Huge Soundtrack - Each level has its own unique song
Oculus Rift Support
Vive Support (coming soon)
Ultrawide Monitor Supported (tested with 3440 x 1440)
60fps achieveable even on low range PCs
Over 100+ levels to drink sodas in
Hundreds of secrets and levels in hidden separate game inside Soda Drinker Pro
Level Select after completing the game
In-game Soda Customization

Cons:

No Leaderboards/Tournament Support currently
Leaves you wishing there was simulated food to wash the soda down with
